item.title: Statistical Inference 1 - MLE & MAP
item.description: Introduction Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE) and Maximum a Posteriori (MAP) estimation are fundamental concepts in statistical inference and understanding these two is key to understanding the motivation behind the most frequently used loss functions like cross-entropy loss, mean-squared error (MSE or L2 loss) and mean absolute error (L1 loss). Assuming a probability distribution $p: \bm{\Omega} \rightarrow \mathbb{R},, p(\bm{x})$, independent samples $\bm{x}^{(1)}, \dots , \bm{x}^{(N)}$ and a set of parameters $\bm{\theta}$ on the domain $\bm{\Theta}$, generative modeling is occupied with fitting a parameterized distribution $p_{\bm{\theta}}(\bm{x})$ to the original data distribution $p(\bm{x})$, such that we can generate new samples $\bm{x}^{(N+i)}\sim p_{\bm{\theta}}(\bm{x}), i>0$ that look as if they came from $p(\bm{x})$.
